options: Tell him that unless he stops you will have to inform the hospital he works for
Don't discuss his cannabis smoking with the patient
Phone the police
Phone the clinical director of anaesthetics to inform him/her
Discuss the potential negative effects of smoking cannabis
questions:
The next patient you see is a 27-year-old ST1 doctor in anaesthetics. His asthma is poorly controlled at the moment. He mentions in passing that he smokes cannabis on his days off..

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
There is no indication from the scenario that the actions of the doctor are adversely affecting his work as an anaesthetist. A doctor has come to you as a patient for medical care.

Phoning the clinical director, or threatening to phone the hospital, are poor options as this breaks confidentiality without just grounds. Whilst smoking cannabis is illegal this is not a matter that should be referred to the police.
question:
The next patient you see is a 27-year-old ST1 doctor in anaesthetics. His asthma is poorly controlled at the moment. He mentions in passing that he smokes cannabis on his days off..

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation

GMC94
Confidentiality guidance

options: Explain and apologise to the patient
Arrange to speak to the doctor who made the error
Take no action
Delete the reported allergy from the notes
Complete a clinical incident form but elect not to mention it to avoid unnecessary worry
questions:
You review a 66-year-old man who was seen two weeks ago with a chest infection. At the time, he was prescribed a course of amoxicillin by a colleague. Today he is better but you notice on screen he has been noted to have a previous allergy to penicillins.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
This is a simple error. Fortunately, it appears not to have harmed the patient but it should still be managed as any error would be. The patient should be given an explanation and an apology (A).

Speaking to the doctor who made the error (B) ensures that she/he is aware of the issue and allows them to address why this happened.

Following this, a clinical incident form should be completed (C). This allows for frequent errors to be recognised so that systems may be changed. Not mentioning the mistake to the patient is unprofessional and not in keeping with GMC guidance.

Taking no action (D) is a poor option as it does not address any of the issues.

Deleting the allergy (E) is dangerous - he may have had an allergy to a specific penicillin, for example co-amoxiclav.
question:
You review a 66-year-old man who was seen two weeks ago with a chest infection. At the time, he was prescribed a course of amoxicillin by a colleague. Today he is better but you notice on screen he has been noted to have a previous allergy to penicillins.

Deleting the allergy (E) is dangerous - he may have had an allergy to a specific penicillin, for example co-amoxiclav.

options: Ask your colleagues whether you can swap the dates of your annual leave with them
Speak to your clinical supervisor
Call in sick on the day and go to the wedding
Ask one of your colleagues to cover you on the day so you can leave for a few hours to go to the wedding and then return before handover
If all else fails, miss the wedding
Complain to your clinical supervisor that the rota coordinator is incompetent and purposely did not give you leave
Ask one of your colleagues to cover your shift and you will do them a favour in return or pay them
Go to the wedding. Explain to your team the next day that you were under the impression that your leave had been approved
questions:
You are a F2 working in the Stroke Unit. It is your friend's wedding but you were unable to get annual leave on the dates you requested, despite emailing the rota coordinator 3 months in advance.

Choose the THREE most appropriate actions to take in this situation.
notes: The 3 best answers are options 1,2 and 5. Option 1 shows that you are being proactive by trying to arrange a swap with your colleagues. Option 2 is always good in this situation. Your clinical supervisor is your point of call and by highlighting the issue to them, they may be able to assist or further inform you about what to do. Option 5 is the final correct option in this scenario. Although missing the wedding is not an ideal outcome, it is better than the other options which include lying (option 6), falsifying leave (options 3 and 8) and putting undue stress on colleagues to cover for you (options 4 and 7).
question:
You are a F2 working in the Stroke Unit. It is your friend's wedding but you were unable to get annual leave on the dates you requested, despite emailing the rota coordinator 3 months in advance.

GMC94
Confidentiality guidance

options: Ask the family what they want you to do
Tell the family what has happened
Contact the district nurses who set-up the syringe driver
Say nothing to the family
Stop the syringe driver temporarily and observe
Continue the syringe driver at the current rate if he is comfortable
Call 999 for an ambulance
questions:
You asked to do a home visit on an 84-year-old man with terminal lung cancer who has a DNA CPR order in place. He is expected to die within the next few days and has been on a syringe driver for the past 48 hours which contains diamorphine and cyclizine. On arriving the family say they think he is getting weaker. On review, he is drowsy and has a respiratory rate of 6 / min. You check the syringe driver to find it has been set up in error to run over 12 instead of 24 hours.

Choose the THREE most important steps to take in this situation.
notes:
In this scenario, a terminal ill man has the symptoms of an opioid overdose caused by an error in the set-up of the syringe driver. The dilemma is whether to intervene and cause potential upset given that the patient is likely to die in the next couple of days anyway.

The syringe driver should be stopped temporarily until the effects of the excessive opioids have worn off. This will require careful observation to ensure the patient doesn't continue to deteriorate (e.g. further slowing of the respiratory rate) or experiences pain if the analgesia becomes suboptimal. Failure to act means you are allowing an excessive morphine dose to hasten the death of a patient. The 'double-effect' principle cannot be applied here as this relates to doses of opioids needed to control pain, not excessive doses. The family should therefore be informed about the error and the district nurses contacted to prevent further errors. It may also be appropriate to fill in a clinical incident form.
question:
You asked to do a home visit on an 84-year-old man with terminal lung cancer who has a DNA CPR order in place. He is expected to die within the next few days and has been on a syringe driver for the past 48 hours which contains diamorphine and cyclizine. On arriving the family say they think he is getting weaker. On review, he is drowsy and has a respiratory rate of 6 / min. You check the syringe driver to find it has been set up in error to run over 12 instead of 24 hours.

options: Prescribe the medication that the patient has requested
Tell the patient that you will consider the evidence surrounding the inhaler
Tell the patient that you are unable to make such decisions and to book in with one of the partners
Review the patients current asthma treatment
Discuss other licenced options that are currently recommended by NICE / BTS
Explain to the patient that the medication is not licenced to be used in the UK
Refer the patient for a respiratory consultation in order to assess suitability
Submit a request to the clinical commissioning group
questions:
You are on a GP rotation and a patient who is a known asthmatic attends your clinic. She wants to be prescribed an inhaler which is currently not licenced in the UK for asthma; however, you are aware that it has been used in other countries to promising effect.

Choose the THREE most appropriate actions to take in this situation.
notes:
This question deals with the issue of off-licence prescribing. See the GMC guidelines for comprehensive advice. As doctors, it is within your remit to prescribe off-licence medications, particularly if unlicensed medications are required in order to meet your patient's needs. However, this should be done when there is a relevent clinical need and is often done by, or the advice of, specialists.

The best options are to review her current treatment (D) - is she taking it correctly. You should discuss the next options in line with standard guidance (E) and discuss the relevant legal/regulatory situation (F).

Options B and C raise false hope and just push the problem to another time. Option G is not appropriate as it's not clear her asthma has reached the stage requiring specialist input.
question:

options: Phone the ward sister in-charge.
Drive back to work (30 minute drive) to correct your mistake.
Phone the FY1 covering the ward
Phone the medical registrar on call.
Check the patient first thing in the morning for any side effects.
questions:
You are a ST doctor working in respiratory medicine. Once you've arrived home for the night you realise that you accidentally prescribed penicillin to a penicillin allergic patient that afternoon.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes: The nurse in-charge will know the patient and will be able to stop the drug being given and also find a doctor to change the prescription (1). The FY1 is also in a good position to correct the mistake but might not be available immediately to prevent administration(3). The medical registrar on call is a less appropriate option as they will be busy and not necessarily know the patient (4). By returning to work you are putting yourself at risk from fatigue especially as you are driving (2). This will not correct your mistake and puts the patient at huge risk (5).
question:
You are a ST doctor working in respiratory medicine. Once you've arrived home for the night you realise that you accidentally prescribed penicillin to a penicillin allergic patient that afternoon.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
question_notes: The nurse in-charge will know the patient and will be able to stop the drug being given and also find a doctor to change the prescription (1). The FY1 is also in a good position to correct the mistake but might not be available immediately to prevent administration(3). The medical registrar on call is a less appropriate option as they will be busy and not necessarily know the patient (4). By returning to work you are putting yourself at risk from fatigue especially as you are driving (2). This will not correct your mistake and puts the patient at huge risk (5).

GMC94
Confidentiality guidance

options: Tell the mother to come into the practice to explain in person
Tell the mother that her daughter came to the practice but do not disclose the details of the appointment
Tell the mother that she should try to speak to her daughter about the appointment
Explain to the mother that you must respect her daughter's confidentiality
Ask the mother to speak to one of the GP partners
Tell the mother about the appointment details as her daughter is under 16
Call the patient and ask her to speak to her mother about her appointment
Explore the mother's concerns
Tell the mother that is inappropriate for her to request this information from the practice
Speak to the GMC
questions:
You are a Foundation Year 2 doctor working in General Practice. One of your patients, a 15-year-old girl, has visited you requesting contraception. She discloses that she has a 15-year-old boyfriend but wishes to start contraception before becoming sexually active. You provide her with a list of options and arrange a follow-up appointment. Later that day, you receive a phone call from her mother requesting to know the details of the appointment.

Choose the THREE most appropriate actions to take in this situation.
notes:
The GMC's good medical practice clearly states that doctors must maintain confidentiality with their patients unless there are concerns for their safety or the safety of the public. Although the patient is a child, if they are deemed to be 'Gillick competent', they have the capacity to make informed decisions regarding their treatment and have the right to confidentiality. Therefore, it is most appropriate to explain to the mother that you must respect her daughter's confidentiality (D). You should explore any concerns that the mother may have (H) and encourage her to discuss these concerns with her daughter (C). That way, the mother may be able to find out why her daughter attended the GP practice without your involvement.

Disclosing information regarding the daughter's appointment to the mother either in person (A) or over the phone (F) is inappropriate and a breach of patient confidentiality. Equally, telling the mother that the daughter came to practice but refusing to give further information (B) breaches confidentiality. Calling the daughter and asking her to speak to her mother about the appointment (G) is inappropriate and puts additional stress on her. Asking the mother to speak to a GP partner (E) deflects the responsibility onto someone else - you should be able to deal with this request as a FY2 doctor. Telling the mother that her request is inappropriate (I) may come across as rude and confrontational and could damage your rapport going forward. Speaking to the GMC (J) is unwarranted at this stage and unlikely to be helpful.
question:
You are a Foundation Year 2 doctor working in General Practice. One of your patients, a 15-year-old girl, has visited you requesting contraception. She discloses that she has a 15-year-old boyfriend but wishes to start contraception before becoming sexually active. You provide her with a list of options and arrange a follow-up appointment. Later that day, you receive a phone call from her mother requesting to know the details of the appointment.

Disclosing information regarding the daughter's appointment to the mother either in person (A) or over the phone (F) is inappropriate and a breach of patient confidentiality. Calling the daughter and asking her to speak to her mother about the appointment (G) is inappropriate and puts additional stress on her. Asking the mother to speak to a GP partner (E) deflects the responsibility onto someone else - you should be able to deal with this request as a FY2 doctor. Telling the mother that her request is inappropriate (I) may come across as rude and confrontational and could damage your rapport going forward. Speaking to the GMC (J) is unwarranted at this stage and unlikely to be helpful.
title: Consent in children
body:
The law around consent in children is complicated. However, as a rough guide:
  • patients less than 16 years old may consent to treatment if they are deemed to be competent (an example is the Fraser guidelines, previously termed Gillick competence), but cannot refuse treatment which may be deemed in their best interest
  • between the ages of 16-18 years it is presumed patients are competent to give consent to treatment
  • patients 18 years or older may consent to treatment or refuse treatment

With regards to the provision of contraceptives to patients under 16 years of age the Fraser Guidelines state that all the following requirements should be fulfilled:
  • the young person understands the professional's advice
  • the young person cannot be persuaded to inform their parents
  • the young person is likely to begin, or to continue having, sexual intercourse with or without contraceptive treatment
  • unless the young person receives contraceptive treatment, their physical or mental health, or both, are likely to suffer
  • the young person's best interests require them to receive contraceptive advice or treatment with or without parental consent

options: Tell your colleagues about what happened in the mess to ensure they are aware of the doctors limitations
Say nothing, stay with the patient and take over when he asks for help
Go and get the A&E consultant
Say nothing at the time but fill in a clinical incident form
Immediately voice your concerns and ask him to stop
questions:
You are a ST1 doctor in General Medicine. During an on-call you are in A&E seeing a patient who has a pneumothorax. On arriving you find the A&E ST2 doctor attempting to perform an aspiration. He appears to about to insert the needle at the wrong landmark.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
If you have concerns regarding the management of a patient it is important to act on them. It may be that you are wrong - the ST2 doctor may actually be performing the aspiration using a recognised, safe technique. This should not however stop you voicing your concerns - failing to do so may put the patient at risk.

If you feel unable to do you should discuss your concerns with someone who is in a position to act. Saying nothing puts the patient at potential harm. Filling in a clinical incident form after the event will not alter this.

Spreading rumours in the mess about a doctors ability is unprofessional and unlikely to lead to a resolution of the problem.
question:
You are a ST1 doctor in General Medicine. During an on-call you are in A&E seeing a patient who has a pneumothorax. On arriving you find the A&E ST2 doctor attempting to perform an aspiration. He appears to about to insert the needle at the wrong landmark.

(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
question_notes:

options: Look at what the procedure involves online and then do it.
Go ahead using your limited knowledge of the procedure.
Ask him what to say and then do it.
Refuse as you feel you are too junior.
Speak to the patient first and if they don't have any questions then do it.
questions:
Your consultant phones you from theatre and asks you to consent one of his patients for a hemicolectomy as he forgot to do it this morning and doesn't want to delay the list. You have never assisted in such an operation and have no real idea of the complications other than infection and bleeding.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
The person performing a surgical procedure should be the one obtaining consent (4). Asking the consultant how you should complete the task you are unfamiliar with is the best option in a bad situation (3). Obtaining the information using other reputable sources is also good (1). You are recognising your limitations by speaking to the patient first and seeing if you can proceed however with little knowledge on the procedure you will not be able to give them important information that they may not ask about (5). Going ahead taking none of the above into account is the least appropriate option (2).

The GMC state that the doctor undertaking the procedure is responsible for obtaining consent, however they can delegate this task to someone providing they are suitably qualified and trained and have sufficient knowledge of the procedure and risks involved. The overall responsibility of ensuring consent has been obtained rests with the doctor performing the procedure.

GMC. Good medical practice. Responsibility for seeking patients consent.

GMC94
Confidentiality guidance

options: Ask him if he would like to talk to you about it
Carry his bleep for a few hours as a favour
Suggest he informs his clinical supervisor
Suggest he sees his GP
Offer to give him some clinical skills teaching
questions:
You are a newly qualified junior doctor on your first rotation in stroke medicine. You start to become concerned that your colleague may be struggling to adjust to his new role. He appears unsure and anxious when asked to do even simple tasks such as requesting bloods and frequently asks you for assistance. What do you do?

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation (A=Most appropriate; E= Least appropriate)
notes: The best option is to discuss this sensitively with him. If you can find out what he is struggling with and if there is anything that can be done. Often with doctors in difficulty we find there is something underlying the outward problem, e.g. issues at home or mental health problems. This may be an ideal opportunity for a colleague to confide in you. Once you have established what the problem is, it is usually best for the doctor to speak with his supervisor for some more formal support. Offering him some teaching may be useful and is always a nice way to bond with other team members. Also, teaching is a core competency for all junior doctors and so you will gain skills yourself from doing this. Suggesting he sees his GP may be the correct thing to do if you find out he is suffering outside of work but from the information we are given it may not be appropriate to suggest this. The worst answer is to carry his bleep - it does not provide a long-term solution to his problem and may compromise patient care as if a medical emergency/cardiac arrest call goes out he will not receive it and his help may be required.

Once you have established what the problem is, it is usually best for the doctor to speak with his supervisor for some more formal support. Offering him some teaching may be useful and is always a nice way to bond with other team members. Also, teaching is a core competency for all junior doctors and so you will gain skills yourself from doing this. Suggesting he sees his GP may be the correct thing to do if you find out he is suffering outside of work but from the information we are given it may not be appropriate to suggest this. The worst answer is to carry his bleep - it does not provide a long-term solution to his problem and may compromise patient care as if a medical emergency/cardiac arrest call goes out he will not receive it and his help may be required.
title: GMC guidance: doctor's health
body:
The General Medical Council (GMC) makes it explicitly clear that you should not rely on your own judgement of the risk posed by your health to your patients. They state that this should be done by an 'appropriately qualified healthcare professional'. You must seek and follow their advice on any changes to your work necessary. In this case therefore, the only appropriate choice is to consult occupational health.

Risks posed to patients by your own health
  • 'If you know or suspect that you have a serious condition that you could pass on to patients, or if your judgement or performance could be affected by a condition or its treatment, you must consult a suitably qualified colleague.'
  • 'You must follow their advice about any changes to your practice they consider necessary.'
  • 'You must not rely on your own assessment of the risk to patients.'

Good Medical Practice, domain 2, subsections 28-30, GMC 2013
concept: You must support colleagues who have problems with performance, conduct or health
